factoid: Princess Mary felt a strange feeling in herself.
Princess Mary acknowledged that feeling.
Princess Mary's father's illness began.
Princess Mary stayed with her father expecting something to happen.
Princess Mary's personal desires awakened.
Princess Mary's personal hopes awakened.
Thoughts of a life free from fear of her father floated in Princess Mary's imagination.
Thoughts of the possibility of love floated in Princess Mary's imagination.
Thoughts of family happiness floated in Princess Mary's imagination.
These thoughts floated like temptations of the devil.
Princess Mary had questions about how to order her life after her father's illness.
The thoughts were temptations of the devil.
Princess Mary knew the thoughts were temptations of the devil.
Princess Mary believed prayer was the sole weapon against the devil.
Princess Mary tried to pray.
Princess Mary assumed a prayerful attitude.
Princess Mary looked at icons while praying.
Princess Mary repeated the words of a prayer.
Princess Mary could not pray.
Princess Mary felt a different world had taken possession of her.
The new world was one of strenuous and free activity.
The new world was opposed to the spiritual world Princess Mary had been confined in.
Princess Mary's greatest comfort had been prayer.
Princess Mary could not weep.
Worldly cares took possession of Princess Mary.
It became dangerous to stay in Boguchárovo.
News of the French approaching spread in all directions.
A homestead ten miles from Boguchárovo was looted by French marauders.
The doctor insisted on moving the prince.
The provincial Marshal of the Nobility sent an official to Princess Mary to persuade her to leave quickly.
The head of the rural police urged Princess Mary to leave quickly.
The French were about twenty-five miles from Boguchárovo.
French proclamations were circulating in the villages.
If Princess Mary did not take her father away before the fifteenth, he could not answer for the consequences.
Princess Mary decided to leave on the fifteenth.
Preparations and orders occupied Princess Mary all day.
Princess Mary spent the night of the fourteenth in the room next to the prince's room.
Princess Mary did not undress that night.
Princess Mary heard the prince's groans and muttering.
Princess Mary heard the creak of the prince's bed.
Princess Mary heard the steps of Tíkhon and the doctor when they turned the prince over.
Princess Mary listened at the door.
Princess Mary thought the prince's mutterings were louder than usual.
Princess Mary thought the prince was turned over more often.
Princess Mary could not sleep.
Princess Mary went to the door several times.
Princess Mary wished to enter but did not decide to do so.
Princess Mary saw the prince's signs of anxiety.
Princess Mary knew the prince found his anxiety unpleasant.
Princess Mary noticed the prince turned from her look with dissatisfaction.
Princess Mary knew that entering during the night would irritate the prince.
Princess Mary had never felt so grieved for the prince.
Princess Mary had never been so afraid of losing the prince.
Princess Mary recalled her life with the prince.
Princess Mary found expressions of the prince's love for her in his words and acts.
Occasionally temptations of the devil surged into Princess Mary's imagination.
These thoughts were about what would happen after the prince's death.
These thoughts were about how her new life would be ordered.
Princess Mary drove these thoughts away with disgust.
The prince became quiet toward morning.
Princess Mary fell asleep.
Princess Mary woke late.
The sincerity that comes with waking revealed Princess Mary's primary concern about her father's illness.
Princess Mary listened behind the door.
Princess Mary heard the prince groan.
Princess Mary said to herself that things were still the same.
Princess Mary cried that she wanted the prince's death.
Princess Mary felt loathing for herself.
Princess Mary washed.
Princess Mary dressed.
Princess Mary said her prayers.
Princess Mary went out to the porch.
Carriages without horses stood in front of the porch.
Things were being packed into the vehicles.
It was a warm, gray morning.
Princess Mary stopped at the porch.
Princess Mary was horrified by her spiritual baseness.
Princess Mary tried to arrange her thoughts before going to her father.
The doctor came downstairs.
The doctor went out to Princess Mary.
The doctor said the prince was a little better today.
The doctor said he was looking for Princess Mary.
The doctor said the prince's head was clearer.
The doctor said the prince was asking for Princess Mary.
Princess Mary's heart beat violently at the news.
Princess Mary grew pale.
Princess Mary leaned against the wall to keep from falling.
Seeing the prince was a torment of joy and terror for Princess Mary.
Talking to the prince was a torment of joy and terror for Princess Mary.
Feeling the prince's eyes on Princess Mary was a torment of joy and terror.
Princess Mary's soul was overflowing with dreadful, wicked temptations.
The doctor said "Come."
